mdRecord.dcterms:title: Crackerbox, The, exterior|general view
mdRecord.dcterms:publisher: Rector and Visitors of the University of Virginia
mdRecord.dcterms:description: The Crackerbox is one of the few surviving outbuildings of the Academical Village and may date from as early as 1826. The small, two-story building is located behind Hotel F on the East Range, and served as both a kitchen and quarters for the hotelkeeper's slaves. … the current building most likely represents the original footprint. The occupation history of the Crackerbox is unclear, but it likely served as a kitchen through the 1800s, as an automobile garage sometime prior to 1929, and in 1960, once extensively renovated, was converted into the two-student-room dormitory it is today. — http://juel.iath.virginia.edu/node/175 [work]
mdRecord.dcterms:isPartOf: James Murray Howard University of Virginia Historic Buildings and Grounds Collection
mdRecord.dcterms:subject: Architecture and City Planning
